{{Distinguish|Muhlenberg Brothers}}
{{Infobox company | name = Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd.| logo = [[File:Muhlenberg Greene Architects Logo.png|220px|Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd.]] | type = [[Private company]] | industry = [[Architecture]] | traded_as = | foundation = 1920 | founder = [[Frederick Augustus Muhlenberg|Frederick A. Muhlenberg]] | num_employees = 13 | homepage = {{URL|http://mg-architects.com}} }}
'''Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd.''' is a full-service architecture firm, in continuous operation since 1920, and was one of the predominant architecture/engineering firms in [[Reading, Pennsylvania]], during the first half of the 20th century.
Muhlenberg Greene Architects was originally established in 1920 as '''Frederick A. Muhlenberg, Registered Architect'''. Since its founding, Muhlenberg Greene Architects lists over 3,500 commissions to its credit,<ref>Muhlenberg Greene Architects. [http://mg-architects.com/history "History"], ''Muhlenberg Greene Architects'', Retrieved on 13 May 2013.</ref> including many landmarks in the city of [[Reading, Pennsylvania|Reading]], such as [[Shillington, Pennsylvania|Berks Heim]], the [[Medical Arts Building (Reading, Pennsylvania)|Reading Medical Arts Building]], and [[George Baer Hiester|Stokesay Castle]].
== Founder ==
The original founder of Muhlenberg Greene Architects, [[Frederick Augustus Muhlenberg]] II, [[Fellow of the American Institute of Architects|FAIA]] was renowned for his endeavors in [[architecture]], politics, community, social services, and the military.<ref>{{cite news|title=F.A. Muhlenberg Succumbs at 92|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=21 Jan 1980}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-congressman, architect is dead|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=21 Jan 1980}}</ref> Although Frederick Muhlenberg opened an office in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] around 1917-1919,<ref>{{cite news|last=Muhlenberg|first=Frederick A.|title=Announcement|url=http://mg-architects.com/wp-content/uploads/Muhlenberg-announcement-19192.jpg|date=1 May 1919}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Muhlenberg, Frederick Augustus (1887-1980)|url=http://www.philadelphiabuildings.org/pab/app/ar_display.cfm/26286|publisher=Philadelphia Architects and Buildings|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref> by 1920, the practice was located exclusively in Reading, and the firm continued through several reorganizations to its present form as Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd.
Frederick A. Muhlenberg, Registered Architect, 1920–1930
Muhlenberg, Yerkes, Muhlenberg, 1930<ref>{{cite news|title="Young Reading" Takes Another Step Forward|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0HAhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LYgFAAAAIBAJ&dq=muhlenberg-yerkes&pg=1870%2C1347067|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=7 Dec 1930}}</ref><ref name="muhl nueb">{{cite news|title=Muhlenberg and Nuebling Viewed as "Drafted" Candidates for Council|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1VohAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pYcFAAAAIBAJ&dq=muhlenberg%20architect%20medical%20arts&pg=3910%2C2508395|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=18 Aug 1933}}</ref> – 1957<ref name="philadelphiabuildings">{{cite web|title=Muhlenberg, Yerkes & Muhlenberg (fl. 1930 - 1954)|url=http://www.philadelphiabuildings.org/pab/app/ar_display.cfm/46757|publisher=Philadelphia Architects and Buildings|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="Proposals 1957">{{cite news|title=Sealed Proposals|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JgYrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K5gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4538%2C2406180|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=23 Aug 1957}}</ref> :(Partners were Frederick A. Muhlenberg, Simeon M. Yerkes,<ref>{{cite web|title=Yerkes, Simeon M. (1889 - ca. 1958)|url=http://www.philadelphiabuildings.org/pab/app/ar_display.cfm/21419|work=Philadelphia Architects and Buildings|publisher=The Athenaeum of Philadelphia|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref> Charles Rick Muhlenberg (died 7/15/1953),<ref name=AIA2>{{cite web|title=Charles Rick Muhlenberg|url=http://communities.aia.org/sites/hdoaa/wiki/Wiki%20Pages/ahd1031714.aspx|publisher=The American Institute of Architects|accessdate=10 Jul 2013}}</ref> and Frederick H. Muhlenberg.<ref name="philadelphiabuildings" /><ref name=retire />
Muhlenberg and Yerkes Associates, 1957 – 1959<ref name="Kutztown 1958">{{cite news|title=State Names Architect|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rxArAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7ZsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4343%2C3879640|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=28 Jul 1958}}</ref>
Frederick A. Muhlenberg & Associates, 1959 – 1965
Muhlenberg-Greene-Veres, 1965 – 1972 :(Partners were Frederick A. Muhlenberg, Lawrence A. Greene, Jr. and Elmer Veres)<ref name=retire />
Muhlenberg-Greene Architects, 1972 – 1977<ref name=retire /> :(Partners were Frederick A. Muhlenberg and Lawrence A. Greene, Jr.)
Muhlenberg-Greene Architects, 1977-1980 :(Lawrence A. Greene, Jr., Sole Proprietor)
Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd., 1980 – Present<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Engineering News Record|year=1980|volume=205|page=310|publisher=McGraw-Hill}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=The Office: Magazine of Information Systems and Management|date=July 1982|url=https://books.google.com/?id=1BW8XmG9RfoC&dq=%22muhlenberg+greene+architects%22|title=The Office: Magazine of Information Systems and Management}}</ref>
Frequently confused with the [[Muhlenberg Brothers]], an architecture/engineering firm also operating in Reading, Pennsylvania during the first half of the 20th century, Muhlenberg Greene Architects was never affiliated with Muhlenberg Brothers’ firm, although [[Frederick Augustus Muhlenberg|Frederick Muhlenberg]] does have familial ties with the Brothers.
Officially retiring from the firm in 1977,<ref name=retire>{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Heather|title=Architect Redesigns Work|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pN0hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=raAFAAAAIBAJ&dq=stokesay%20muhlenberg-greene&pg=5479%2C6543649|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=30 Oct 1977}}</ref> one week after his 90th birthday, Mr. Muhlenberg still came to the office daily until physical limitations prevented him from doing so about a year later. [[Frederick Augustus Muhlenberg|Fred Muhlenberg]] died on January 19, 1980, at 92 years of age.
== Present organization ==
Following Mr. Muhlenberg's retirement in 1977, the Firm became the sole proprietorship of Lawrence A. Greene, Jr, (who had, at that time, been a partner of the firm for 25 years)<ref name=retire /> until January 1, 1980 when the present corporation, Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd., was established. The original principals/stockholders were Lawrence (Larry) A. Greene, Howard Quaintance, and James (Jim) E. Dockey. In 1983, Dennis W. Rex was added as a principal/stockholder of the Firm. In 1998, John R. Hill became a principal/stockholder. The current principals are Larry Greene, Howard Quaintance, Dennis W. Rex, and John R. Hill. Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd. is a member of the [[American Institute of Architects]] and the [[U.S. Green Building Council]],<ref name=LEED>{{cite web|title=Directory: Muhlenberg Greene Architects, Ltd.|url=http://www.usgbc.org/organizations/muhlenberg-greene-architects-ltd|publisher=USGBC|accessdate=10 Jul 2013}}</ref> and many of the staff are [[LEED Professional Exams|LEED Accredited Professionals]].

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Paintings made in accordance with traditional Japanese artistic conventions" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Paintings made in accordance with traditional Japanese artistic conventions}} {{Distinguish|Nihongo}} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:Hishida Shunsō 001.jpg|thumb|''Rakuyō'' (落葉, Fallen Leaves) by [[Hishida Shunsō]], [[Important Cultural Property (Japan)|Important Cultural Property]] (1909)]] [[File:Kobayashi Fruit.jpg|thumb|''Fruit'' by [[Kobayashi Kokei]] (1910)]] [[File:Enbu by Hayami Gyoshu.jpg|thumb|''Enbu'' (炎舞, Dance of Flames) by [[Gyoshū Hayami]], Important Cultural Property (1925)]] [[File:Madaraneko by Takeuchi Seiho.jpg|thumb|''Madaraneko'' (斑猫, Tabby Cat) by [[Takeuchi Seihō]], Important Cultural Property (1924)]] [[File:Jo-no-mai by Uemura Shoen.jpg|thumb|''Jo no Mai'' (序の舞, Noh Dance Prelude) by [[Uemura Shōen]] (1936)]]
'''''Nihonga''''' ({{lang|ja|日本画}}, "[[Japan]]ese-style paintings") are [[Japanese painting]]s from about 1900 onwards that have been made in accordance with traditional Japanese artistic conventions, techniques and materials. While based on traditions over a thousand years old, the term was coined in the [[Meiji period]] of [[Empire of Japan|Imperial Japan]], to distinguish such works from Western-style paintings, or ''[[Yōga]]'' ({{lang|ja|洋画}}).
== History == The impetus for reinvigorating traditional painting by developing a more modern Japanese style came largely from many artist/educators, which included; [[Shiokawa Bunrin]], [[Kōno Bairei]], [[Tomioka Tessai]], and [[art critic]]s [[Okakura Tenshin]] and [[Ernest Fenollosa]] who attempted to combat [[Meiji period|Meiji Japan's]] infatuation with Western culture by emphasizing to the Japanese the importance and beauty of native Japanese traditional arts. These two men played important roles in developing the curricula at major art schools, and actively encouraged and patronized artists.
''Nihonga'' was not simply a continuation of older painting traditions. In comparison with ''[[Yamato-e]]'' the range of subjects was broadened. Moreover, stylistic and technical elements from several traditional schools, such as the ''[[Kanō school|Kanō-ha]],'' ''[[Rinpa school|Rinpa]]'' and ''[[Maruyama Ōkyo]]'' were blended together. The distinctions that had existed among schools in the [[Edo period]] were minimized.
However, in many cases ''Nihonga'' artists also adopted realistic Western painting techniques, such as [[perspective (graphical)|perspective]] and shading. Because of this tendency to synthesize, although ''Nihonga'' form a distinct category within the Japanese annual [[Japan Art Academy|Nitten]] exhibitions, in recent years, it has become increasingly difficult to draw a distinct separation in either techniques or materials between ''Nihonga'' and ''Yōga''.
The artist [[Tenmyouya Hisashi]] has (b. 1966) developed a new art concept in 2001 called "Neo-Nihonga".
=== Development outside Japan === ''Nihonga'' has a following around the world; notable ''Nihonga'' artists who are not based in Japan are [[Hiroshi Senju]], , [[United States|American]] artists [[Makoto Fujimura]] and Judith Kruger, and [[Miyuki Tanobe]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://judithkruger.com/|title=SELECTED WORK|publisher=Judith Kruger}}</ref> and Indian artist Madhu Jain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madhujain.com|title=Madhu Jain|publisher=}}</ref> Taiwanese artist Yiching Chen teaches workshops in Paris.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yiching.free.fr/|title=NIHONGA - Peinture japonaise YICHINGCHEN|first=|last=YICHINGCHEN|publisher=}}</ref> Judith Kruger initiated and taught the course "Nihonga: Then and Now" at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and at the Savannah, Georgia Department of Cultural Affairs.
Contemporary Nihonga has been the mainstay of New York's Dillon Gallery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dillongallery.com|title=EXHIBITIONS|publisher=Dillon + Lee}}</ref> Key artists from the "golden age of post war Nihonga" from 1985 to 1993 based at Tokyo University of the Arts have produced global artists whose training in Nihonga has served as a foundation. [[Takashi Murakami]], [[Hiroshi Senju]], Norihiko Saito, Chen Wenguang, Keizaburo Okamura and [[Makoto Fujimura]] are the leading artists exhibiting globally, all coming out of the distinguished Doctorate level curriculum at Tokyo University of the Arts. Most of these artists are represented by Dillon Gallery.
== Materials == ''Nihonga'' are typically executed on ''[[washi]]'' (Japanese paper) or ''eginu'' ([[silk]]), using brushes. The paintings can be either monochrome or polychrome. If monochrome, typically ''[[Inkstick|sumi]]'' (Chinese ink) made from [[soot]] mixed with a glue from fishbone or animal hide is used. If polychrome, the [[pigment]]s are derived from natural ingredients: [[mineral]]s, shells, [[coral]]s, and even [[Gemstone|semi-precious stone]]s like [[malachite]], [[azurite]] and [[cinnabar]]. The raw materials are powdered into 16 gradations from fine to sandy grain textures. A [[Animal glue#Hide glue|hide glue]] solution, called ''nikawa'', is used as a binder for these powdered pigments. In both cases, water is used; hence ''nihonga'' is actually a [[Watercolor painting|water-based medium]]. ''Gofun'' (powdered [[calcium carbonate]] that is made from cured [[oyster]], [[clam]] or [[scallop]] shells) is an important material used in ''nihonga''. Different kinds of ''gofun'' are utilized as a ground, for under-painting, and as a fine white top color.
Initially, ''nihonga'' were produced for hanging scrolls (''[[kakemono]]''), hand scrolls (''[[emakimono]]''), sliding doors (''[[fusuma]]'') or folding screens (''[[byōbu]]''). However, most are now produced on paper stretched onto wood panels, suitable for framing. Nihonga paintings do not need to be put under glass. They are archival for thousands of years.
== Techniques == In monochrome ''Nihonga'', the technique depends on the modulation of ink tones from darker through lighter to obtain a variety of shadings from near white, through grey tones to black and occasionally into greenish tones to represent trees, water, mountains or foliage. In polychrome ''Nihonga'', great emphasis is placed on the presence or absence of outlines; typically outlines are not used for depictions of birds or plants. Occasionally, [[wash (visual arts)|washes]] and layering of pigments are used to provide contrasting effects, and even more occasionally, [[gold]] or [[silver]] leaf may also be incorporated into the painting.
== See also == * [[List of Nihonga painters]] * [[Japanese painting]]
== References == {{Reflist}} * Briessen, Fritz van. ''The Way of the Brush: Painting Techniques of China and Japan''. Tuttle (1999). {{ISBN|0-8048-3194-7}} * Conant, Ellen P., Rimer, J. Thomas, Owyoung, Stephen. ''Nihonga: Transcending the Past: Japanese-Style Painting, 1868-1968''. Weatherhill (1996). {{ISBN|0-8348-0363-1}} * Setsuko Kagitani: ''Kagitani Setsuko Hanagashû - Flowers'', Tohôshuppan, Tokyo, {{ISBN|978-4-88591-852-0}} *Weston, Victoria. ''Japanese Painting and National Identity: Okakura Tenshin and His Circle''. Center for Japanese Studies University of Michigan (2003). {{ISBN|1-929280-17-3}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Primary Colors | image = Primaryposter.jpg | caption = Promotional film poster | director = [[Mike Nichols]]{{cite news|title= Travolta reveals Clinton's prime sense of humour|publisher= [[The Independent|Independent]]|author=David Lister|date=May 14, 1998|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/travolta-reveals-clintons-prime-sense-of-humour-1159912.html|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} | producer = Mike Nichols
Jonathan Krane
Neil Machlis | screenplay = [[Elaine May]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[Primary Colors (novel)|Primary Colors]]''|[[Joe Klein (journalist)|Joe Klein]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[John Travolta]] * [[Emma Thompson]] * [[Billy Bob Thornton]] * [[Adrian Lester]] * [[Maura Tierney]] * [[Paul Guilfoyle]] * [[Larry Hagman]] * [[Kathy Bates]]}} | music = [[Ry Cooder]] | cinematography = [[Michael Ballhaus]] | editing = [[Arthur Schmidt (film editor)|Arthur Schmidt]] | studio = [[Mutual Film Company]] | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1998|3|20}} | runtime = 143 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $65 million{{cite news|title= Don't You Wish You Could Get Buttered Popcorn in Civics Class?|publisher= [[The New York Times]] |url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20F15FC395C0C708EDDAA0894D0494D81|author=Bernard Weinraub|date=March 23, 1998 |accessdate=January 24, 2011}} | gross = $52.1 million{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=primarycolors.htm|title=Primary Colors|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=2011-06-29}} }} '''''Primary Colors''''' is a 1998 American [[comedy-drama]] film directed by [[Mike Nichols]]. The screenplay by [[Elaine May]] was [[film adaptation|adapted]] from the novel [[Primary Colors (novel)|''Primary Colors: A Novel of Politics'']], a ''[[roman à clef]]'' about [[Bill Clinton presidential campaign, 1992|Bill Clinton's first presidential campaign in 1992]], which was originally published anonymously, but in 1996 was revealed to have been written by journalist [[Joe Klein (journalist)|Joe Klein]], who had been covering Clinton's campaign for ''[[Newsweek]]''.{{cite news|title= What the Movie Gets —and What It Doesn't |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |author=David Lauter|date=March 15, 1998|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/mar/15/entertainment/ca-28949|accessdate=January 24, 2011}}{{cite news|title= Just What He Didn't Need Right Now; Movies: Will 'Primary Colors,' a thinly veiled slice of presidential life, hurt or help Bill Clinton? |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |author=Faye Fiore|date=March 2, 1998|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/mar/02/entertainment/ca-24508|accessdate=January 24, 2011}}[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9901E6DB1F39F93BA25754C0A960958260 Columnist's Mea Culpa: I'm Anonymous], Doreen Carvajal, ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 18, 1996 The film starred [[John Travolta]], [[Emma Thompson]], [[Billy Bob Thornton]], [[Kathy Bates]], [[Maura Tierney]], [[Larry Hagman]] and [[Adrian Lester]]. It was critically acclaimed but was a [[box office bomb]], earning $52 million from a $65 million budget. Bates was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for her performance, and May was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay]]. ==Plot== Young political idealist and grandson of a civil rights leader Henry Burton ([[Adrian Lester]]) is recruited to join the campaign of Jack Stanton ([[John Travolta]]), a charismatic Southern governor who is trying to win the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] nomination for [[President of the United States]]. Henry is impressed by Stanton's genuine warmth and empathy with people. He joins Stanton's inner circle of political advisers: Stanton's formidable wife, Susan Stanton ([[Emma Thompson]]); ruthless political strategist Richard Jemmons ([[Billy Bob Thornton]]); intelligent and attractive spokeswoman Daisy Green ([[Maura Tierney]]); and sly political operator Howard Ferguson ([[Paul Guilfoyle]]) as they journey to [[New Hampshire]], the first state to hold a [[New Hampshire primary|presidential primary]]. After Stanton completes an impressive debate performance against his Democratic rivals, Henry’s ex-girlfriend shows up to question Stanton about his arrest for an anti-war protest during the [[1968 Democratic Convention]] in Chicago. In addition it's revealed that Stanton called a U.S. senator to help him get released then Stanton persuaded the mayor of Chicago to have his police record expunged. The team becomes worried that Stanton’s past indiscretions may be used against him by the press and his political opponents. They hire Jack and Susan's old friend, tough but unbalanced Libby Holden ([[Kathy Bates]]), to investigate allegations that could be used by Stanton's political opponents to undermine his candidacy such as Stanton's notorious womanizing. One of Stanton's mistresses and Susan's hairdresser, Cashmere McLeod ([[Gia Carides]]), produces secret taped conversations between them to prove they had an affair. Henry discovers that the tapes have been doctored, so Libby tracks down the man responsible for the tapes and forces him at gunpoint to confess his guilt in a signed letter to the American public. The campaign is then rocked by a fresh allegation when Stanton's old friend, "Big Willie" McCollister ([[Tommy Hollis]]) approaches Henry to tell him that his 17-year-old daughter Loretta (who worked for the Stantons as a babysitter) is pregnant and that Stanton is the father. Henry and Howard tell Willie he must allow his daughter to undergo an [[amniocentesis]] to determine paternity. Although they convince Willie to remain silent on the issue, Henry is nonetheless sickened and disillusioned with the experience. Realizing the campaign is falling behind in the polls, Stanton's team adopt a new strategy. Stanton begins going on the offensive by attacking his nearest rival, Senator Lawrence Harris ([[Kevin Cooney]]) for casting anti-[[Israel]] votes and favoring cuts in [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] and [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]]. Harris confronts Stanton during a radio talk show in Florida but suffers two heart attacks after the encounter. He suffers a medical setback, subsequently withdraws from the race, and is replaced by his friend, former Florida governor Fred Picker ([[Larry Hagman]]). Picker's wholesome, straight-talking image proves an immediate threat to the Stanton campaign. Jack and Susan send Henry and Libby on an [[opposition research]] mission on Picker's past. They discover from his ex-brother-in-law, Eduardo Reyes ([[Tony Shalhoub]]), that Picker had a [[cocaine]] addiction as governor, which led to the disintegration of his first marriage. They also meet with Picker's cocaine supplier Lorenzo Delgado ([[John Vargas]]), with whom Picker had a [[homosexual]] affair. Not expecting the information to ever be used, Libby and Henry share their findings with Jack and Susan, but are dismayed when they both decide to leak the information to the press. Libby says that if Jack does so, she will reveal that he tampered with the results of the paternity test, proving that he slept with Willie's daughter. Libby commits suicide after she realizes she spent her life idealizing Jack and Susan only to learn how flawed they truly are. Racked with guilt over Libby's death, Stanton takes the incriminating information to Picker, and apologizes for seeking it out. Picker admits to his past indiscretions, and agrees to withdraw from the race and to endorse Stanton. Henry intends to quit the campaign, admitting he has become deeply disillusioned with the whole political process. Stanton begs Henry to reconsider, persuading him that the two of them can make history. Months later, President Stanton is dancing at the Inaugural Ball with [[First Lady]], Susan. He shakes the hands of all his campaign staff, the last of whom is Henry. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[John Travolta]] as [[Governor of Arkansas]] (later [[President of the United States]]) Jack Stanton * [[Emma Thompson]] as First Lady of Arkansas (later [[First Lady of the United States]]) Susan Stanton * [[Billy Bob Thornton]] as Richard Jemmons * [[Kathy Bates]] as Libby Holden * [[Larry Hagman]] as Governor Fred Picker * [[Adrian Lester]] as Henry Burton * [[Stacy Edwards]] as Jennifer Rogers * [[Maura Tierney]] as Daisy Green * [[Diane Ladd]] as Mamma Stanton * [[Paul Guilfoyle]] as Howard Ferguson * [[Kevin Cooney]] as Senator Lawrence Harris * [[Rebecca Walker]] as March Cunningham * [[Caroline Aaron]] as Lucille Kaufman * [[Tommy Hollis]] as William "Fat Willie" McCullison * [[Rob Reiner]] as Izzy Rosenblatt * [[Ben L. Jones]] as Arlen Sporken * [[J. C. Quinn]] as Uncle Charlie * [[Allison Janney]] as Miss Walsh * [[Robert Klein]] as Norman Asher * [[Mykelti Williamson]] as Dewayne Smith * [[Robert Easton (actor)|Robert Easton]] as Dr. Beauregard * [[Geraldo Rivera]] as himself * [[Charlie Rose]] as himself * [[Larry King]] as himself * [[Bill Maher]] as himself * [[Sophia Choi]] as herself * [[Chelcie Ross]] as Charlie Martin * [[Tony Shalhoub]] as Eddie Reyes * [[John Vargas]] as Lorenzo Delgado * [[Gia Carides]] as Cashmere McLeod {{div col end}} ==Production== Following the publication of the book in 1996, director Mike Nichols paid more than $1 million for the screen rights. The film was scripted by Elaine May, who had collaborated with Nichols in a [[Nichols and May|comedy double-act]] in the 1950s and 60s.{{cite web|last1=Kashner|first1=Sam|title=Who’s Afraid Of Nichols & May?|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2013/01/nichols-and-may-reunion-exclusive|website=Vanity Fair|accessdate=5 June 2016}} At the [[Cannes Festival]], Thompson said she did not base her performance on [[Hillary Clinton]], while Travolta said he based his on several presidents, but mostly on [[Bill Clinton]]. Nichols was criticized for cutting an interracial love scene from the final version of the film. He responded that he had removed the scene because of unfavorable reactions from a preview audience. The film also generated controversy for its depiction of a Clinton-like character as it was also released close to the [[Lewinsky scandal]].{{cite news|title= With Its American Themes, Can 'Primary Colors' Cash In Abroad? |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=May 16, 1998|author=Mark Saylor|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/may/16/entertainment/ca-50153|accessdate=January 24, 2011}}{{cite news|title= They All Have a Secret |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=March 15, 1998|author=Patrick Goldstein|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/mar/15/entertainment/ca-28947|accessdate=January 24, 2011}}{{cite news|title= Cinema: True Colors|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|author=Richard Corliss and Jeffrey Ressner|date=March 16, 1998}}{{cite news|title= Cinema: Tale Of Two Bills|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|author=Eric Pooley|date=March 16, 1998|url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,987986,00.html|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} ==Reception== The film received a positive reception from critics. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety']]''s reviewer called it a "[[film à clef]]" and said that the American public was likely to accept it as a factual account because it so closely mirrored real life characters and events. The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' gave high marks to the movie, noting Travolta's close mirroring of [[Bill Clinton]], but describing Thompson's character as actually not based on [[Hillary Clinton]]. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' called Travolta "Clintonian". ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'' gave accolades to the character portrayals of Bill and Hillary Clinton. Syndicated reviewer [[Roger Ebert]] said the movie was "insightful and very wise about the realities of political life" and ''The Cincinnati Enquirer'' said the film was a "nuanced dissection of how real American politics work". In a negative review, Jeff Vice of the ''[[Deseret News]]'' wrote that the last half of the movie dragged, Travolta's performance seemed more like an impersonation than actual acting, the movie lacked subtlety or depth, and it was loaded with cheap and obvious jokes. Nevertheless, Vice wrote that "solid support is provided by Maura Tierney, Larry Hagman, and Stacy Edwards". ''Primary Colors'' currently holds an 80% rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 75 reviews. ===Box office=== The film earned a disappointing box office gross,{{cite news|title= 'Grease' Beats 'Primary' but Doesn't Rock the Boat; Box office: Revived musical enjoys a $13-million opening, but Oscar-winner 'Titanic' is No. 1 for the 15th straight weekend. |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=March 30, 1998|author=Robin Rauzi|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/mar/30/entertainment/ca-34154|accessdate=January 24, 2011}}{{cite news|title= Travolta Films Tail 'Titanic' |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=March 31, 1998|author=Robert W. Welkos|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/mar/31/entertainment/ca-34372|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} only taking $39 million domestically and $13 million in foreign markets, for a worldwide total gross of $52 million against a budget of $65 million. ==Soundtrack== The soundtrack album, featuring music by and produced by [[Ry Cooder]], was released in March 1998.Billboard - 28 Mar 1998 - Page 55 "VARIOUS ARTISTS Music From The Motion Picture Soundtrack Primary Colors; Music By Ry Cooder"Holger Petersen - Talking Music - 2011 -Page 296 "Movie soundtracks, however, kept him creative, at home, and paying the bills. ... That led to Wim Wenders (Paris, Texas; Buena Vista Social Club), Louis Malle (Alamo Bay), and Mike Nichols (Primary Colors) asking him to soundtrack their films" ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em|refs= {{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2242/is_n1563_v268/ai_18395598/|title=Primary Colors: A Nover of Politics|author=Richard K. Thompson|work=Contemporary Review|date=April 1996|accessdate=January 25, 2011}} {{cite news|title= Primary Colors|publisher= [[Deseret News]]|url= http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700001460/Primary-Colors.html|author=Jeff Vice|date=March 20, 1998|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} {{cite news|title= Primary Colors|publisher= [[Chicago Sun Times]]|author=Roger Ebert|date=March 20, 1998|url= http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19980320/REVIEWS/803200304|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} {{cite news|title= Primary Colors|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|author=Lisa Schwarzbaum |date=March 27, 1998|url= http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,282380,00.html|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} {{cite news|title= Inspired Insinuation|publisher= The Los Angeles Times|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/mar/20/entertainment/ca-30676|date=March 20, 1998|author=Kenneth Turan|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} {{cite news|title= Primary by a landslide|publisher= [[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]|author=Margaret A. McGurk|date=1998|url= http://cincinnati.com/freetime/movies/mcgurk/primarycolors.html|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} {{cite news|title= Primary Colors|publisher= Variety|date=March 12, 1998|author=Todd McCarthy|url= http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117906781?refcatid=31|accessdate=January 24, 2011}} }} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | last=Palmer | first=William J. | year=2009 | chapter=The American President | title=The Films of the Nineties: The Decade of Spin | publisher=Palgrave Macmillan | pages=84–92 | isbn=0-230-61344-6 }} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0119942|Primary Colors}} * {{Allmovie title|160671|Primary Colors}} * {{tcmdb title|331364|Primary Colors}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|primary_colors|Primary Colors}} {{Mike Nichols|state=expanded}} {{Bill Clinton}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Primary Colors}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:1990s comedy-drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American political comedy films]] [[Category:American satirical films]] [[Category:American political satire films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:Films scored by Ry Cooder]] [[Category:Films about elections]] [[Category:Films based on American novels]] [[Category:Films about Bill Clinton]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Bill Clinton]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Hillary Clinton]] [[Category:Screenplays by Elaine May]] [[Category:Films directed by Mike Nichols]] [[Category:Films set in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Films shot in New Orleans]] [[Category:Mutual Film Company films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Films whose writer won the Best Adapted Screenplay BAFTA Award]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Rock the Vote | logo = Rock the Vote logo.png | logo_size = 200px | founded_date = 1990 in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]]<ref name=hard>{{cite news|last1=Duhigg|first1=Charles|title=Rock the Vote Is Stuck in a Hard Place|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/feb/07/business/fi-rockthevote7|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=February 7, 2006}}</ref> | location = [[Washington, D.C.]], United States | area_served = United States | focus = [[Voter registration]], [[Youth vote|youth voting]] | method = Online mobilization, field organizing, entertainment community | homepage = {{URL|http://rockthevote.com}} }}
'''Rock the Vote''' is a [[non-profit organization]], progressive-aligned group in the [[United States]] whose stated mission is "to engage and build the political power of young people."<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.rockthevote.com/about-us/|publisher=Rock The Vote|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
The organization was founded in 1990 by Virgin Records America Co-Chairman Jeff Ayeroff, to encourage young people to vote.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Contrera|first1=Jessica|title=Lil Jon and Lena Dunham team up to take on what Madonna and Chuck D pioneered|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2014/10/07/lil-jon-and-lena-dunham-team-up-to-take-on-what-madonna-and-chuck-d-pioneered/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref> It is geared toward increasing voter turnout among voters ages 18 to 24.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lurie|first1=Stephen|title=Millennial turnout is crucial. Too bad pols have no idea what young people care about.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2014/10/31/millennial-turnout-is-crucial-too-bad-pols-have-no-idea-what-young-people-care-about/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=October 31, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Beaucar Vlahos|first1=Kelley|title=Youth Activist Groups Target Voter Turnout|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2003/12/11/youth-activist-groups-target-voter-turnout/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Fox News|date=December 11, 2003}}</ref> Rock the Vote is known for its celebrity spokespeople and its partnership with [[MTV]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Benjamin|title=Rock the Vote Gets Angry in New Ads|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/rock-vote-angry-ads/story?id=25930607|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=ABC News|date=October 3, 2014}}</ref>
==History== Rock the Vote was founded in 1990 by Jeff Ayeroff with Virgin America co Chair Jordan Harris and Virgin Executive Beverly Lund. Later they hired Jodi Uttal and then [[Steve Barr (educational innovator)|Steve Barr]], a campaign worker and political fundraiser, who became "co-founders" for their contribution to Rock the Vote. Rock the Vote supported the [[National Voter Registration Act of 1993]], commonly referred to as the "motor voter" bill, which expanded access to voter registration. It was signed into law by [[Bill Clinton|President Bill Clinton]]. The law requires state governments to offer voter registration opportunities to any eligible person who applies for or renews a driver's license or public assistance.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cloward|first1=Richard|last2=Pivin|first2=Frances Scott|title=Why Americans Still Don't Vote: And why Politicians Want it that Way|date=2000|publisher=Beacon Press|isbn=9780807004494|page=247}}</ref>
In 1996, Rock the Vote created the first telephone voter registration system, 1-800-REGISTER, followed by the first online voter-registration system, NetVote, later that year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flanagin|first1=Jake|title=Here’s Why You Should Turn Out and Rock the Vote|url=http://op-talk.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/10/09/heres-why-you-should-turn-out-and-rock-the-vote/?_r=0|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=October 9, 2014}}</ref>
"We supported Rock the Vote," said [[Radiohead]]'s [[Thom Yorke]], "but – because of the way the whole political system works – it does seem rather odd to be choosing between one unworkable, outdated system and another. We need to go beyond that – because, at the moment, it's just [[Cowboys and Indians (disambiguation)|Cowboys and Indians]]."<ref>{{cite journal|first= Caitlin |last= [[Caitlin Moran|Moran]] |title= Everything was just fear. |magazine= ''[[Select (magazine)|Select]]'' |date= July 1997 |page= 86}}</ref>
With [[CNN]], Rock the Vote organized "America Rocks the Vote," a 2003 Democratic presidential candidates forum at [[Faneuil Hall]] in Boston.<ref>{{cite news|title=CNN, Rock the Vote to co-sponsor Democratic candidate forum|url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/ALLPOLITICS/10/01/elec04.prez.rock.vote/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=CNN|date=October 1, 2003}}</ref>
Rock the Vote has expressed support for a [[public health insurance option]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mattera|first1=Jason|title=Obama Zombies: How the Liberal Machine Brainwashed My Generation|date=2010|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439172094|page=154}}</ref> It signed on to [[Health Care for America NOW!]], a progressive political coalition that supported passage of the [[Affordable Care Act]]. In 2009, Rock the Vote ran a campaign encouraging people to refuse to have sex with those who opposed what they regarded as a reform of American health care.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rock the Vote Asks Supporters to Withhold Sex to Pass Health Care Reform|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/12/21/rock-vote-asks-supporters-withhold-sex-pass-health-care-reform/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Fox News|date=December 21, 2009}}</ref>
During the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential election]], Rock the Vote drew criticism from [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] officials such as [[Republican National Committee]] chairman [[Ed Gillespie]] for sending a mock [[military draft|draft]] notice to over 600,000 e-mail addresses. The message included the words "[[Selective Service System]]" and read "You are hereby ordered for induction into the Armed Forces of the United States, and to report to a polling place near you" on November 2, ([[Election Day (United States)|Election Day]]). The Rock the Vote logo and a facsimile of [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary]] [[Donald Rumsfeld]]'s signature appeared at the bottom of the message. In addition, Rock the Vote created [[public service announcement]]s featuring the subject of the draft.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rock The Vote, MTV Irk GOP|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/65818/rock-the-vote-mtv-irk-gop|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Billboard Magazine|date=November 2, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sisto|first1=Christine|title=Rock the Democratic Vote|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/389978/rock-democratic-vote-christine-sisto|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=National Review|date=October 16, 2014}}</ref> Besides making the PSAs available to large cable systems, they also paid to run them on a random sample of small cable systems where they could measure the effects. Turnout was three percentage points higher among 18-19-year olds in these sample areas than in the control group covered by other similar small cable systems; there was less effect above age 22.<ref name="vavreck">{{Cite journal |last=Green |first=Donald P. |last2=Vavreck |first2=Lynn |date=2008 |title=Analysis of Cluster-Randomized Experiments: A Comparison of Alternative Estimation Approaches |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Donald_Green4/publication/31382310_Analysis_of_Cluster-Randomized_Experiments_A_Comparison_of_Alternative_Estimation_Approaches/links/00b4951f9a12acc282000000.pdf |journal=Political Analysis |language=en |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=138–152 |doi=10.1093/pan/mpm025 |issn=1047-1987}}</ref><ref name="green" />
According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', Rock the Vote experienced financial problems in the aftermath of the 2004 election. It emerged from the election $700,000 in debt, and its president resigned in the summer of 2005 "amid disagreements about the organization's direction."<ref name=hard/>
In 2008, Rock the Vote ran the largest non-partisan youth voter registration drive in the nation's history by getting 2.6 million young voters registered.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGuirt|first1=Mary|title=Young Black Turnout a Record in 2008 Election|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=8140030|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=ABC News|date=July 21, 2009}}</ref>
In November 2012 and 2013 Rock the Vote experimented with Facebook ads to encourage voter turnout by telling people the number of days remaining until the election and which of their friends "liked" the countdown. The ads were shown to over 400,000 adults, randomly selected from a base over 800,000. Rock the Vote had helped many of them register. The ads did not increase turnout in the experimental group, compared to the control group who did not get the ads.<ref name="green">{{Cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/922072845 |title=Get out the vote : how to increase voter turnout |last=Green |first=Donald P. |isbn=081572568X |edition= Third |location=Washington, D.C. |pages=97–98, 101, 120–121 |oclc=922072845}}</ref> In 2012 they also experimented with text message reminders to 180,000 people who had provided their mobile numbers. Texts the day before the election raised turnout six tenths of a percentage point, while texts on election day lowered turnout.<ref name="green" />
In advance of the 2014 elections, Rock the Vote released a video titled "Turn Out For What." It was a parody of [[Lil Jon]] and [[DJ Snake]]'s song "[[Turn Down for What]]".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kreps|first1=Daniel|title=Lena Dunham, Lil Jon Team for Rock the Vote's 'Turn Out for What' Video|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/lena-dunham-lil-jon-team-for-rock-the-votes-turn-out-for-what-video-20141007|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref> The video sought to encourage youth voter turnout and featured [[reproductive rights]], [[marijuana legalization]], [[global warming]], [[LGBT rights]], student debt, [[gun control]] and [[deforestation]] as reasons why young people might want to vote.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Peligri|first1=Justin|title=Lil Jon and Lena Dunham 'Turn Out' in new Rock The Vote video|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/07/politics/new-rock-the-vote-video/|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=CNN|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref> The video was criticized by some Republicans who said it had a disproportionate representation of liberal issues.<ref>{{cite news|title='Rock the Vote' celebrities called out for not voting in last mid-term election|url=http://abc7.com/politics/rock-the-vote-celebrities-called-out-for-not-voting/380155/|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=ABC News|date=November 4, 2014}}</ref> The video was also criticized because several of the celebrities who appeared in it, including [[Lena Dunham]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Natasha Lyonne]] and [[Darren Criss]], had not voted in the previous midterm election.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lombardi|first1=Ken|title=Some Rock The Vote midterm PSA stars didn't vote in last midterm|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/rock-the-vote-midterm-psa-celebrities-didnt-vote-in-last-midterm/|accessdate=24 April 2015|publisher=CBS News|date=November 3, 2014}}</ref>
The day after the [[2016 U.S. presidential election]], Rock the Vote President and Executive Director Carolyn DeWitt issued a statement on behalf of the organization expressing disappointment with the election of [[Donald Trump]] and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] congressional victories.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@RockTheVote/rock-the-vote-responds-to-2016-presidential-election-results-fac7a420c815|title=Rock the Vote Responds to 2016 Presidential Election Results|first=Rock the|last=Vote|date=9 November 2016|publisher=Medium}}</ref>
==Democracy Class== Rock the Vote: Democracy Class is a program put on by Rock the Vote. It is designed to educate high school students about voting, elections and governance. The [[nonpartisan]] lesson plan uses music, pop culture, video, classroom discussion and a [[mock election]] to teach young people the skills to navigate the [[elections]] process and engage as active citizens.<ref name=nation>{{cite news|last1=Rothberg|first1=Peter|title=Democracy Class|url=http://www.thenation.com/blog/166987/democracy-class|accessdate=6 February 2015|publisher=The Nation|date=March 22, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ramesh|first1=Indu|title=Rock the Vote campaigns to spark young voters|url=http://www.dukechronicle.com/articles/2010/08/27/rock-vote-campaigns-spark-young-voters#.VNU61sYhwt8|accessdate=6 February 2015|publisher=Duke Chronicle|date=August 26, 2010}}</ref> On Democracy Day 2011, teachers in all 50 states committed to teaching Democracy Class in more than 1,100 classrooms.<ref name=nation/> High school students in Democracy Classes participate in mobile polls that assess their viewpoints on public policy issues.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Lauren|title=Mobile is key to connecting with young voters: Rock the Vote|url=http://www.mobilemarketer.com/cms/news/strategy/12247.html|accessdate=6 February 2015|publisher=Mobile Marketer|date=March 2, 2012}}</ref>
== Celebrity spokespeople == This is a partial list of celebrities who have appeared in [[public service announcements]] for Rock the Vote.
{{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Aerosmith]] * [[Against Me!]] * [[Christina Aguilera]] * [[Rachel Bilson]] * [[Adam Brody]] * [[Bootsy Collins]] and [[Buckethead]] * [[Chris Cornell]] * [[Miranda Cosgrove]] * [[Darren Criss]] * [[Miley Cyrus]] * [[Deee-Lite]] * [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] * [[Robert Downey Jr.]] * [[Daniel Dumile]] * [[Macy Gray]] * [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] * [[Maggie Gyllenhaal]] * [[Reverend Horton Heat]] * The cast of ''[[Jack & Bobby]]'' * [[Janet Jackson]] * [[Michael Jackson]] * [[Samuel L. Jackson]] * [[Kinky (band)|Kinky]] * [[Lush (band)|Lush]] * [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] * [[Ricky Martin]] * [[Megadeth]] * [[Brittany Murphy]] * The cast of ''[[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]'' * [[Donny Osmond]] * [[P. Diddy]] * [[Sarah Jessica Parker]] * [[The Ramones]] * [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] * [[Romeo Miller|Romeo]] * [[Rooster Teeth]] * [[Peter Sarsgaard]] * [[Slaughter (band)|Slaughter]] * [[Michael Stipe]] * [[Justin Timberlake]] * [[Benicio del Toro]] * [[Paul Van Dyk]] * [[Eddie Vedder]] * [[Scott Weiland]] * [[will.i.am]] * [[XO Stereo]] * [[Draymond Green]] * [[Kendall Jenner]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.rockthevote.com/ Rock the Vote] *[http://www.rockthevote.com/get-involved/register-voters/ Voter Registration Technology]

'''Sculptors Guild,''' a society of sculptors<ref name="Guildinfo">[http://www.sculptorsguild.org Sculptors Guild Home Page]</ref> who banded together to promote public interest in contemporary sculpture, was founded in 1937. Signatories to the original corporation papers (Sculptors Guild, Inc.) were Sonia Gordon Brown, [[Berta Margoulies]], Aaron J. Goodelman, [[Chaim Gross]] (who became the first President), Minna Harkavy, [[Milton Horn]], [[Concetta Scaravaglione]], Warren Wheelock, and [[William Zorach]]. The inaugural exhibit of the Guild was held April 12 - May 31, 1938, on a vacant lot at Park Avenue and 39th St. This outdoor exhibit, the first of its kind in New York City, hosted 40,000 visitors paying an admission price of ten cents to view the work. Owing to the tremendous success of this first exhibit, the Brooklyn Museum held an exhibit of contemporary American sculpture by Guild members, October 21- November 27, 1938.
The 57 founding members of the Sculptors Guild were: {{Div col|colwidth=18em}} *Saul Baizerman *Aaron Ben-Shmuel *Simone Brangier Boas *Sonia Gordon Brown *Harold Cash *Albino Cavalito *[[Cornellia Van A. Chapin]] *[[Robert Cronbach]] *Louise Cross *John Cunningham *[[Alice Decker]] *[[Jose de Creeft]] *Jean De Marco *[[Jose De Rivera]] *Hunt Diederich *Alfeo Faggi *[[Herbert Ferber]] *Paul Fiene *[[John Bernard Flannagan]] *Hy Freilicher *Mark Freidman *[[Eugenie Gershoy]] *[[Enrico Glicenstein]] *Maurice Glickman *[[Vincent Glinsky]] *Aaron J. Goodelman *Dorothea Greenbaum *[[Chaim Gross]] (first President) *[[Genevieve Karr Hamlin]] *[[Minna Harkavy]] *[[Alonzo Hauser]] *[[Milton Hebald]] *[[Milton Horn]] *John Hovannes *[[Margaret Brassler Kane]] *[[Nathaniel Kaz]] *[[Oronzio Maldarelli]] *[[Paul Manship]] *[[Berta Margoulies]] (first Secretary) *[[Dina Melicov]] *George Meyers *David Michnick *Ward Montague *[[Hugo Robus]] *[[Marion Sanford]] *[[Hélène Sardeau]] *[[Concetta Scaravaglione]] *[[Louis Slobodkin]] *[[Cesare Stea]] *[[Mary Tarleton]] *T. Trajan *Polygnotos Vagis *Marion Walton *Nat Werner *[[Anita Weschler]] (first Treasurer) *Warren Wheelock *Adolf Wolff *[[William Zorach]] {{div col end}} The Sculptors Guild continues today as an advocacy organization with a diverse membership. Activities have expanded to include the annual “dressing” of the windows of Saks 5th Avenue, NYC, and participation in exhibitions abroad, such as the 1993 exhibition in Kyoto, Japan, and the 2008 international art fairs at Art Cologne and Supermarket Stockholm. The Sculptors Guild has a presence on New York’s historic Governors Island, with annual indoor and outdoor exhibitions, carving workshops and gallery talks. In 2010 the Sculptors Guild opened a gallery space and office on the second floor in [[Dumbo, Brooklyn]]. In September 2016, they moved into an office space on the second floor at the Renee and Chaim Gross Foundation, in [[Greenwich Village]] at 256 LaGuardia Place, NY, NY 10012 and continue to have summer exhibitions on Governors Island.
2017 will be the Sculptor Guild's 80th year, and will be celebrated with a momentous member exhibition curated by [[John Yau]] at the historic [[Westbeth Gallery]] for the month of February. This exhibition will include past and current members highlighting the vast forms of sculpture members have explored over past 80 years.
Membership is by invitation and/or submission to the Admissions Committee.
